title: Colin Thackery, 89, now 'ready for female company' three years after wife died

We’re at Universal Records’ headquarters in London’s Kings Cross, a swanky place where the walls are crowded with modern art and every second person looks like they might be a pop star.

It’s not where you’d expect to find an octogenarian war veteran, clad in a scarlet Chelsea Pensioner’s coat and decorated with medals.

But Colin Thackery strolls in looking confident and not in the least bit fazed.

It’s no wonder – more than 10 million people watched him win Britain’s Got Talent in June, and at the ripe age of 89, he recently became the oldest person in history to land their first record deal.

(Image: BGT)

‘It feels a bit mad, if I’m honest,’ he says, as we settle down on a sofa to chat.

‘A few months ago, life was very ordinary, now all of a sudden it’s on its head.

‘My daughter worried it might be too much for me, but I told her it’s like being on a roundabout – it’s getting a bit fast, but one day it’s going to stop.

‘I’m not an aspiring young pop singer.

‘If it stops, it stops, and it will have been lovely.’

Yet Colin’s career appears to be on the up and up.

He’s just finished recording his first album, has signed up to do a tour in the new year, and recently featured on an enormous, five-platform poster at London’s Waterloo Station.

‘It was a blooming great big thing,’ he says with a chuckle.

‘I said to the record company people, “What on earth are you up to?!”’

And if that wasn’t enough, he’s due to perform at the Royal Variety Show in November.

‘I’ve served Her Royal Highness my whole life, and now I’m going to sing for her and all,’ he says, clearly delighted.

(Image: Collect Unknown)

Colin is ridiculously energetic for someone approaching 90.

He puts his good health down to a mixture of Pilates and the gym.

Oh, and a good old-fashioned power nap.

‘I learnt the knack in the army – there was no time to sleep with the threat of nuclear war,’ he says.

‘I can catnap anywhere.’

His rise to fame began in the unlikeliest of places: a dare over a curry buffet at the Royal Chelsea Hospital, the care home for veterans where he lives.

‘A friend told me BGT was looking for contestants, and knowing I loved singing, he dared me to apply,’ explains Colin.

‘I said, “Don’t be silly. What would they want with an old duffer like me?”

But I signed up because I wanted to get the scarlet coat on the telly.’

He fondly strokes his iconic Chelsea Pensioner livery as he talks.

Colin was astonished when he was called for audition after audition.

(Image: Matt Writtle / Evening Standard)

Overwhelmed by the whirlwind of his new-found fame, he didn’t even realise there was a cash prize until just before the semi-final.

‘My granddaughter Alice said, “The money would be nice if you won, Grandad.”

‘I said, “What money?” So she told me it was a £50,000 prize.

‘Well, it wasn’t – it was £250,000!’ he says, beaming.

‘I’m going to leave it all to my four grandchildren to help them get on the property ladder.’

Granddaughter Alice helps Colin with all his social media, which he admits he finds rather baffling, despite being a dab hand with his shiny new iPhone.

‘A few weeks ago Alice said, “Grandad, you’ve got a blue tick,”’ he says, referring to the badge social media companies give to celebrities to confirm they are the real deal.

‘I said, “Have I? Is it catching?”

‘When she explained what it was I asked, “How many things do you have to score to get that?”

‘She just laughed.’

(Image: Collect Unknown)

Sadly, Colin has also experienced the nasty side of fame with some unscrupulous paparazzi.

Invited to sing at a charity event in a nightclub, he was asked to pose with an assortment of glam women, and at one point even had a bottle of vodka thrust upon him, leading to headlines labelling him a ‘party animal’.

‘I don’t even drink vodka,’ he says with a sigh.

‘It was a bit naughty of them and I felt quite put out.

‘I shouldn’t have been so naïve to be trapped into that sort of thing.

‘I’ve been all around the world and spent 25 years in the army – I didn’t think anyone could trick me that way.’

(Image: Philip Coburn)

But for every dodgy pap, Colin has a thousand loyal fans.

He’s inundated with fan mail from people of all ages, including a nine-year-old girl whose bedroom is decorated with all things Colin.

‘I thought, “Gosh, this little girl thinks I’m a film star,” when I saw a picture,’ he says with a chuckle.

He also gets mail of a less innocent nature…

‘I’ve had a few saucy letters too, and I get a bit embarrassed,’ he says.

‘Some women say things like, “I’ve got a house and a car,” and I think, “Bully for you – what do you want me to do about it?”

‘I would love to meet a nice lady, though.

‘I enjoy female company and I’m not too old for romance – although at my age, you want companionship more than anything else.

‘There’s so much to talk about when you’re older – your family, what you’ve done in the past, places you’ve been.’

(Image: Collect Unknown)

Colin was widowed in 2016 after losing his wife Joan to breast cancer.

The couple were together for 66 years, and Colin was naturally devastated by his loss.

‘It was an awful shock after so long together… It’s like cutting off your arm,’ he says, his gaze moving to the window.

‘This person who was your life, for all those years… you’ve grown into that wonderful state of life where you don’t need anything and you’ve got all you want.

‘It was shattering – watching her fight the cancer was the biggest battle of my life.’

That’s a big statement from someone who has been to war.

Although he went on to become a highly decorated veteran, Colin has never forgotten the awful things he saw.

‘You become inured to things,’ he says.

‘The first time you move a body is awful, and then you just stop thinking about it because you’ve seen so many.

‘War is a filthy business.

‘You become an animal – kill or be killed, it’s what it’s all about.’

Colin moved into the Royal Hospital Chelsea after losing Joan, and he now lives alongside 300 other veterans.

(Image: Philip Coburn)

His fellow residents have been mainly over the moon about his success, bringing their visiting families over to introduce them.

But living in close quarters can come with its challenges.

‘There are guys that I mix with who haven’t mellowed and are still completely intolerant.

‘I think that’s awful,’ he says.

‘I always say to them, “Come on, you’ve got to live with the times.”

‘They complain that it wasn’t like this in the old days and I say, “It’s not the old days any more and it never will be again. Things are progressing.”’

We’ve been chatting to Colin far longer than we should, because he’s just got so much to say.

One thing is clear: this is one pensioner who is going places.

After all, there aren’t many people who are planning to spend their 90th birthday singing to a sell-out crowd.

Colin on getting older

‘I wouldn’t want to be young again – I’m happy with my age.

'There’s a lot you don’t have to worry about, like how to get on in life. You’ve accepted what you’ve got and you feel settled.

'I do find failing health tough, though, especially as I was so fit when I was younger.

'The thing that frightens me the most is getting dementia – I sing to the dementia ward once a week, and I’ve seen how dreadful it is.’

How do you spend your Sunday?

■ Lazy lie-in or up with the lark?

I always get up early on a Sunday for Communion.

Beliefs are very important.

■ Pub roast or family lunch?

We love a Sunday roast in my family.

This Sunday I’m going to my granddaughter’s for lunch.

She’s a wonderful cook and her boyfriend is a smashing lad – I wish they would get married.

■ What couldn’t you get through the weekend without?

Eating good food.

I try to eat healthily during the week.

If I don’t want to eat at the hospital, I’ll nip to Wagamama because I love Asian food.

■ Porridge or full English?

I indulge a bit on a Sunday. There’s a restaurant on the King’s Road where I go for a full English. It beats weekday porridge, and I like to sit and read the paper.

- Colin Thackery’s new album Love Changes Everything is out on Decca Records/Syco on December 6
description: The 89 year old Chelsea Pensioner lost his beloved wife Joan in 2016, but he says he's not too old for romance
